title: Numpy-like operations

content.raw: I know you want comments on the YTEP but I can't help myself from saying that an unweighted mean being a sum seems weird to me.
content.html: I know you want comments on the YTEP but I can't help myself from saying that an unweighted mean being a sum seems weird to me.

content.raw: (even though we do that elsewhere....)

Sure -- `sum()` is also on the list of stuff to implement.  `mean()` will probably be *able* to be coerced into doing a sum, but won't be the primary entry point.  I'll update the tests once `sum()` is in.
content.html: Sure -- sum() is also on the list of stuff to implement. mean() will probably be able to be coerced into doing a sum, but won't be the primary entry point. I'll update the tests once sum() is in.

content.raw: OK, I've removed these tests; you can still coerce mean into giving a sum, but it's not tested, and I test something else instead.
content.html: OK, I've removed these tests; you can still coerce mean into giving a sum, but it's not tested, and I test something else instead.

Hi -- I'm ready to start documenting this, but I'm not 100% sure where it should go.  @chummels , @brittonsmith, @ngoldbaum, do you have suggestions about what should be changed, removed, added, etc?
content.html: Hi -- I'm ready to start documenting this, but I'm not 100% sure where it should go. chummels , Britton Smith, Nathan Goldbaum, do you have suggestions about what should be changed, removed, added, etc?

content.raw:
Definitely this page: http://yt-project.org/doc/analyzing/objects.html

Maybe also in the quickstart? Some cookbook examples?
content.html:
Definitely this page: http://yt-project.org/doc/analyzing/objects.html

Maybe also in the quickstart? Some cookbook examples?

content.raw: I agree with @ngoldbaum .  I'd include a section in the objects docs on "alternate form of specifying objects" or something like that and a description of how to use it to subsample the dataset.  Perhaps an additional cookbook recipe would be appropriate too?  Quickstart maybe along with the other use of objects?
content.html: I agree with Nathan Goldbaum . I'd include a section in the objects docs on "alternate form of specifying objects" or something like that and a description of how to use it to subsample the dataset. Perhaps an additional cookbook recipe would be appropriate too? Quickstart maybe along with the other use of objects?

content.raw: Also agreed with @ngoldbaum on a subsection in analyzing/objects.
content.html: Also agreed with Nathan Goldbaum on a subsection in analyzing/objects.

content.raw: I've added documentation to narrative docs.  I think that updating the quickstart should happen in a separate PR, where I'll update it for the ``fields`` object as well.  I will propose that in the other PR too.
content.html: I've added documentation to narrative docs. I think that updating the quickstart should happen in a separate PR, where I'll update it for the fields object as well. I will propose that in the other PR too.

Maybe this should be "rapidly selecting data while doing interactive work on the command line". The way it's currently phrased might be interpreted to mean that selecting data this way is more performant.
content.html: Maybe this should be "rapidly selecting data while doing interactive work on the command line". The way it's currently phrased might be interpreted to mean that selecting data this way is more performant.

content.raw:
Maybe explain that this is 100% equivalent to:

```
ds = yt.load("RedshiftOutput0005")
ad = ds.all_data()
rho = ds['density']
```
content.html:
Maybe explain that this is 100% equivalent to:

ds = yt.load("RedshiftOutput0005")
ad = ds.all_data()
rho = ds['density']

content.raw: Maybe note that this is equivalent to creating a `ds.proj` object and specifying `proj_type='mip'`
content.html: Maybe note that this is equivalent to creating a ds.proj object and specifying proj_type='mip'

content.raw: Maybe note that this is equivalent to the weighted average derived quantity?
content.html: Maybe note that this is equivalent to the weighted average derived quantity?

content.raw: It might be easier to see what to do here if you merge with the tip of the yt branch.
content.html: It might be easier to see what to do here if you merge with the tip of the yt branch.
